name: Bulkhead
title: Bulkhead
description: Learn how to use the MicroProfile Bulkhead policy to prevent cascading failures.

steps.name: Intro
steps.title: What you'll learn
description: Explore how to prevent a single failure from bringing down the entire system. MicroProfile makes this easy to do with its Fault Tolerance feature's Bulkhead policy.

You'll start with a sample online banking scenario and see how it fails when no fault tolerance is implenented. You'll then enable the MicroProfile Fault Tolerance feature and use the Bulkhead policy to prevent the failing method from taking down the whole application. You will explore the two approaches to Bulkhead, semaphore isolation and thread pool isolation, and the parameters used for the annotation. Finally, you will add a fallback class which will be invoked if the BulkheadException is thrown.

sections.name: backgroundConcepts
sections.title: Background concepts
description: We will use the MicroProfile Bulkhead and Asynchronous policies.
Bulkhead
The term bulkhead comes from the structure used in ships to create partitions. In the event of a hull breach, these partitions can be sealed off to prevent the rest of the ship from getting damaged.
The bulkhead pattern in software systems work similarly by isolating failures to prevent the rest of the system from failing.
Asynchronous
Asynchronous means the execution of the client request will be on a separate thread.

steps.name: ExampleScenario
steps.title: Example: Bank Scenario
description: Imagine that you're developing a VirtualFinancialAdvisor (VFA) microservice for a bank to allow online chat with an available financial advisor. The initial implementation of the microservice allows only one financial advisor chat at a time. As you progress through the guide, you could see how the number of available chat session impacts the service and the system.

Implementing Java concurrency using Future and Executors removes the single chat limitation and allows multiple chat sessions available at the same times.
Let us start by adding Future and Executors to the codes.

steps.name: AddLibertyMPFaultTolerance
steps.title: Enabling MicroProfile Fault Tolerance
description: Microprofile fault tolerance is a way for microservices to handle the unavailability of a service by using different policies to guide the execution and result of some logic. The MicroProfile Fault Tolerance 1.0 feature provides an environment to support resilient microservices through patterns that include bulkheads. Enable the MicroProfile Fault Tolerance 1.0 feature in the server.xml of the Liberty server where the Virtual Financial Advisor microservice runs.
instruction: Add the following element declaration inside the featureManager element to the server.xml file, or click <feature>mpFaultTolerance-1.0</feature>. Then, click Save on the editor menu pane.

steps.name: BulkheadAnnotation
steps.title: Adding the @Bulkhead annotation
description: Now that you've seen how our application can easily fail when overloaded, let's fix that by applying the Bulkhead policy. Add @Bulkhead to the serviceForVFA microservice to limit the maximum number of concurrent chat requests.

When @Bulkhead is used by itself, the microservice executes on the current thread. When the maximum number of concurrent chat requests is reached, any subsequent concurrent request fails with BulkheadException.
Configure @Bulkhead using the following parameter:
• value: The maximum number of concurrent requests. This parameter is optional. If the parameter is not specified, the default is 10 requests.
instruction: Add @Bulkhead with a value of 50 on line 20, before the serviceForVFA method, or click @Bulkhead(50). Then, click Run on the editor menu pane.
Click Customer 1 request chat to open a chat session with an available advisor.

Since then 49 more customers have requested chat sessions with an available advisor and all 50 chats are still active. Once the maximum number of concurrent chat requests is reached, the next concurrent chat request is rejected.
Click Customer 51 request chat to get the failure to open a chat session.

steps.name: AsyncBulkheadAnnotation
steps.title: Adding the @Asynchronous annotation with @Bulkhead
description: Using @Bulkhead limits the number of concurrent financial advisor chat requests. After the maximum limit of concurrent requests for a financial advisor is reached, the next concurrent chat request fails. Adding @Asynchronous fixes this problem by allowing additional chat requests to be placed in a waiting queue.

When @Bulkhead is used with @Asynchronous, the microservice is executed on separate thread. This allows to configure the maximum concurrent requests along with the waiting queue size. When a request for a financial advisor cannot be added to the waiting queue, a BulkheadException is thrown.
Configure the waiting queue using the following parameter:

• waitingTaskQueue: The number of requests on the waiting queue. This parameter is optional. If the parameter is not specified, the default is 10 requests. This value only takes effect when @Asynchronous is used.

steps.name: Fallback
steps.title: Adding the @Fallback annotation
description: Using the @Asynchronous and @Bulkhead annotations together allows requests for a financial advisor to be placed in the waiting queue after the number of requests exceeds the specified maximum number of concurrent requests. If the waiting queue fills, a BulkheadException is thrown. Let's add a @Fallback to handle the exception.

Use the @Fallback annotation to identify a method that automatically runs when a BulkheadException occurs. In our scenarios, we add the ServiceFallbackHandler.java that implements the FallbackHandler.class and add the @Fallback annotation to use that class. When the microservice fails, the handle method in the FallbackHandler.class is called. The return type of both methods, ServiceFallbackHandler.handle and BankService.serviceForVFA, must be of type Service, otherwise FaultToleranceDefinitionException is thrown.
instruction:
In BankService.java add the @Fallback(ServiceFallbackHandler.class) annotation on line 9, or click
@Fallback(ServiceFallbackHandler.class).
Then, click Run on the editor menu pane.
Click Customer 1 request chat to open a chat session with an available financial advisor.

Since then 49 more customers have requested chat sessions with an available advisor and all 50 chats are still active. Once the maximum number of concurrent chat requests is reached, the next concurrent chat request is place in the waiting queue.
Click Customer 51 request chat to be place in the waiting queue.

Another 49 customers request chat sessions and are placed in the waiting queue. The codes limit the maximum number of requests on the waiting queue to 50, additional customer request can not be added since the waiting queue is now full.
